titlestmt.titleproper: "Solidarity" Information Office in Canada records CPAA 95.13
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Special Collections staff

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-04-21T10:51-0400

did.unittitle: "Solidarity" Information Office in Canada records
did.abstract: The Solidarity Information Office in Canada was opened in Toronto in 1981, and served as a satellite office of the Solidarity Coordinating Office Abroad in Brussels. Zygmunt Przetakiewicz was the director of the office from 1981 until 1983, and in 1983 Wojciech Gilewski was a director of the office until 1990, when it discontinued operation. The collection consists of extensive correspondence, reports, official publications, press releases and clippings. It covers the years from 1981 until 1990.
did.langmaterial: mostly English and Polish, some publication in French and Spanish.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Collection includes extensive correspondence, reports and memos from the coordinating office in Brussels, press releases, various Solidarity publications abroad, clippings, pamphlets, and information about contacts with other Solidarity groups and offices abroad. It covers the years that the Solidarity Office operated, from 1981 through 1990.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Solidarity Information office in Canada, a non-profit organization, opened in Toronto in 1981, and served as a satellite office of the Solidarity Coordinating Office Abroad in Brussels. Zygmunt Przetakiewicz was the first director of the office from 1981 until 1983. In 1983 Wojcich Gilewski took over and remained director until 1990 when it discontinued operation. The office closely cooperated with Canadian trade unions and Polish Canadian organizations. Their primary duties were to disseminate information about NSZZ “Solidarnosc” throughout Canada and the Polish community. Although operated independently of other social and political organizations, one being the Canadian Labour Union, it was the goal to work amicably with other Polish Canadian groups, such as the Canadian Polish Congress.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Cite as: Solidarity Information Office in Canada, Toronto, Canada (CPAA 95-13). Connecticut Polish American Archives, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.
